title: Europe
content:
Somebody knows something about this typeface? History, author, something else?

Typeface name: Europe (or Capitals Europe?). Geometric (Futura like). France? Greek and latin.  
On the example: Théogonie (with illustrations by Braque), publisher: Adrien Maeght, Paris, 1955. Letterpress.

comments.content: looking at the Latin version.. seems very Futura to me. some of our real type history experts may have more/better info.

The Latin specimen looks like Futura as it was commonly sold at the end of the metal type era. Compare to the specimen in Jaspert's Type Encyclopedia, 1970:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015122712im_/http:/typophile.com/files/FuturaLightSM_6602.jpg)
  
As for history, author etc, here is what Jaspert said:  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015122712im_/http:/typophile.com/files/FuturaInfo_6488.jpg)
  
Renner's early versions had some significant differences in letter-forms, but that may be more info than you want at this stage.  
Don

Peignot also acquired rights to produce a version of Futura, which Deberny & Peignot released in 1930 under the name Europe.  
 [http://www.atypi.org/about-us/whos-who/charles-peignot](http://web.archive.org/web/20131015122712/http:/www.atypi.org/about-us/whos-who/charles-peignot "http://www.atypi.org/about-us/whos-who/charles-peignot")

thank you all.

Exactly, Deberny & Peignot upon the idea of the art director Maximilien Vox acquired rights to produce a version of Futura from Bauer.  
They released Europe in 1931 in France and french colonies. It seems the greek variant is specific to Deberny & Peignot as they produce it punchcutting while Bauer use a pantographic process to directly produce Futura.  
We wrote a book in french about the history of Futura typeface. ISBN 978-2-9155-4239-4
